citation.article-title: Turicibacter sanguinis gen. nov., sp. nov., a novel anaerobic, Gram-positive bacterium.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Turicibacter sanguinis sp. nov.
Turicibacter sanguinis (san'gui.nis. L. masc. gen. n. sanguinis of blood, indicating that the bacterium was isolated from a blood culture)
Gram-positive, long, irregular rod-shaped, chain-forming cells, 0.5-2.0x0.7-7.0 μm, non-spore-forming.
Colonies are greyish white with a convex elevation, but irregular form with spreading, undulating margins.
Chemo-organotrophic, strictly anaerobic, fermentative metabolism.Growth is observed at 25-46 °C, with an optimum at 37 °C.
No growth occurs at pH≤6.5 or pH≥8.0; the pH optimum is 7.5.
Maltose and 5-ketogluconate are the only carbohydrates utilized.
Activities for aglucosidase, α- and b-galactosidase are detected.
Lactate is the main fermentation product.
The major cellular fatty acids are C16:0 (37%), C18:0 (15.5%) and C18:1ω9c (14.5%).
The DNA has a G+C content of 36.9 mol%.

Phylogenetic analysis shows low relatedness to other bacteria (<88% 16S rDNA similarity) and reveals that this novel species is deeply branching in the tree of Gram-positive bacteria with low DNA G+C content, i.e. next to the Mollicutes.
